summary: The main objective of this context assessment is to provide a comprehensive geographicaldescription of the Agroecological Living Landscapes (ALLs) in Makueni and Kiambu counties inKenya. The report covers the economic, environmental, social, and political aspects of the two ALLsand assesses the extent to which agroecological principles have been implemented or practicedwithin these areas. The study broadly focuses on the two selected ALLs, but also incorporates somespecific information from the two ALL host centers: the Drylands Natural Resources Center (DNRC)in Makueni County and the Community Sustainable Agriculture and Healthy Environment Program(CSHEP) in Kiambu County. The information in the document is primarily sourced from secondaryliterature and outputs generated from various Work Packages aimed at characterizing, identifying,and assessing the existing practices and experiences within the two ALLs.
title: Kenya Context Assessment Report: A desk-top review of the context of agroecological principles of Kiambu and Makueni counties

summary: Urgent action is needed to address climate change, land degradation, and biodiversity loss. The Regreening Africa project (2017–2023), recently recognized as a UN World Restoration Flagship, aimed to reverse land degradation over large areas of land for the triple benefit of people, biodiversity, and climate in eight African countries. Based on projections and early lessons learned, the project sought to identify sustainable scaling models to achieve its ambitious targets. The so-called “Asset-Based Community-driven Development (ABCD) in Regreening” project aimed to demonstrate the positive contribution of deliberate community engagement and co-design. The project introduced ABCD sessions to 30 purposively selected community groups in the Regreening intensification sites in western Kenya. ABCD combines a unique set of framings, methods, and processes that focus on people’s assets and agency, and emphasizes the importance of their attitudes toward self and others for sustainable behavior change. To evidence that ABCD intrinsically contributes to sustainable adoption and scaling of Regreening practices, the project developed the F-ACT+ tool to assess the alignment between ABCD and agroecological practices, and collected baseline and endline data from 300 project and 300 non-project participants. Results showed accelerated agroecological integration among ABCD project participants. ABCD participants showed significant improvements in nine agroecological principles and eight system components, particularly in the economic diversification, social values and diets, and knowledge cocreation principles, as well as in the pest and disease, household, and value chain system components. Summary ATT between ABCD and non-ABCD respondents was positive and significant in 10 principles and eight system components. The results support the synergistic contribution of ABCD to projects targeting sustainable behavior change at the individual and collective levels. Due to its focus on outcomes, this study provided limited insight into the specific mechanisms of ABCD, which are the subject of a separate publication on parallel theory-based contribution analysis work.
title: Scaling models for Regreening Africa: enhancing agroecological integration through smallholders’ assets and agency in Kenya

summary: The catalytic effect of climate change on the emergence and prevalence of invasive alien pests along with weak pesticide regulatory frameworks in developing countries calls for a transition towards sustainable pest management. Agro-ecological pest management (APM) offers a nature-based, cost-effective alternative for addressing systemic pest challenges, such as mango fruit fly invasion. We applied a two-part fractional regression to sequentially model APM adoption and intensity decisions among 423 smallholder mango orchard managers from Makueni County, Kenya. Despite APM’s potential, we observed moderate adoption rates (56.7%), with the average adopter implementing only 25% of the APM practices concurrently. Farmers’ socio-psychological attributes significantly influenced both adoption and intensity decisions. While perceptions of technology attributes and institutional and social factors primarily influenced both the adoption and intensity decisions, information constraints, resource endowment, gender and inter-generational factors significantly influenced only the intensity decision. To support the transition from synthetic insecticides to APM measures, policymakers should create more opportunities for awareness creation, training and knowledge co-creation and co-production, particularly through social networks and gender-disaggregated participatory group approaches.
title: Factors influencing adoption of agro-ecological pest management options for mango fruit fly under information constraints: a two-part fractional regression approach

summary: How can communities, scientists, development practitioners and policymakers better understand the impact of their interventions? On September 24, 2024, the Qualitative Studies Group explored this crucial question in a session led by Lisa Elena Fuchs and Sulman Olieko Owili, moderated by Fanny Howland. Lisa is a social and agroecological systems scientist, and expert in sustainable landscape transitions at the Alliance of Bioversity International and CIAT. Sulman is an agricultural economist consulting for IITA, CIFOR-ICRAF, and the Alliance. The session focused on how to leverage data from realist contribution analysis—a method that reveals not just the results of an intervention, but also how it works, which aspects are effective, to what extent, for whom and in what contexts. This approach sheds light on how individual actors within complex systems drive change, offering valuable insights for those working in agroecology, community development, and related fields.
title: Exploring Realist Contribution Analysis: A Dive into Data Use and Modelling

summary: Since its detection in 2003 in Kenya, the invasive fruit fly Bactrocera dorsalis has become a significant threat to mango production and marketing. To combat its impact, many mango producers in Kenya and other Sub-Saharan African countries have relied on synthetic insecticides. However, these insecticides are costly for smallholder farmers and pose environmental impacts and health risks to orchard managers, workers, and consumers. This has prompted the need for more sustainable pest management practices, aligning with global efforts like the United Nations’ ”Decade on Ecosystem Restoration” (2021–2030), which emphasises ecological balance and sustainable agricultural practices. This study investigates the efficiency effects of adopting and intensifying 18 [1] agro-ecological pest management (APM) practices among smallholder mango farmers in Kenya.
title: Heterogeneous efficiency effects of agro-ecological fruit fly management transition and intensification among smallholder mango farmers: a latent class stochastic metafrontier approach

summary: The main objective of this context assessment is to provide a comprehensive geographical description of the Agroecological Living Landscapes (ALLs) in Makueni and Kiambu counties in Kenya. The report covers the economic, environmental, social, and political aspects of the two ALLs and assesses the extent to which agroecological principles have been implemented or practiced within these areas.
title: Kenya Context Assessment Report: A desk-top review of the context of agroecological principles of Kiambu and Makueni counties

summary: Urgent action is needed to address climate change, land degradation, and biodiversity loss. The Regreening Africa project (2017–2023), recognized as a UN World Restoration Flagship, aimed to reverse land degradation over large areas of land for triple benefits. The project introduced Asset-Based Community-driven Development (ABCD) sessions to selected community groups, demonstrating that deliberate community engagement and co-design accelerate agroecological integration and sustainable adoption of regreening practices.
title: Scaling models for Regreening Africa: enhancing agroecological integration through smallholders’ assets and agency in Kenya

summary: Transitioning away from synthetic insecticides, the study uses a two-part fractional regression to model adoption and intensity of agro-ecological pest management (APM) among Kenyan smallholder mango farmers. Although adoption rates are moderate, socio-psychological attributes and factors like information constraints, resource endowment, gender and inter-generational dynamics influence intensity decisions. The findings underscore the need for awareness, training and knowledge co-creation to promote sustainable pest management.
title: Factors influencing adoption of agro-ecological pest management options for mango fruit fly under information constraints: a two-part fractional regression approach

summary: Session exploring realist contribution analysis led by Lisa Elena Fuchs and Sulman Olieko Owili. It covered leveraging data from realist contribution analysis to understand not just outcomes but mechanisms, contexts and actors driving change. The approach offers valuable insights for agroecology and community development interventions.
title: Exploring Realist Contribution Analysis: A Dive into Data Use and Modelling

summary: Poster summarising the efficiency effects of transitioning and intensifying agro‑ecological pest management practices among Kenyan mango farmers using a latent class stochastic metafrontier approach.
title: Heterogeneous efficiency effects of agro‑ecological fruit fly management transition and intensification among smallholder mango farmers: a latent class stochastic metafrontier approach

summary: The article introduces the reflection problem identified by Manski, explaining how simultaneous social interactions make it difficult to separate peer effects from contextual or correlated effects. It discusses endogeneity in group formation, describes advanced econometric methods and network-based approaches, and highlights policy implications for education, agriculture and public health. The author emphasises careful identification strategies and robust econometric techniques to distinguish genuine peer effects from spurious correlations.
title: The Reflection Problem in Econometrics

summary: The article argues that there is no single “magic bullet” for causal inference using observational data. It critiques shortcut methods such as propensity score matching, sensitivity analyses and automated machine learning, noting that they cannot fully address biases from unobserved confounders. Instead, the author advocates for a multi-method approach that integrates robust statistical techniques with domain expertise and careful consideration of assumptions to draw credible causal insights.
title: Why There is No “Magic Bullet” for Causal Inference using Observational Data

summary: Introduces the Collatz conjecture and demonstrates the CollatzR R package for exploring Collatz sequences. The post explains functions like compute_collatz(), generate_collatz(), and visualize_collatz(), which compute, generate and visualize the sequences. It discusses applications of the conjecture in algorithmic efficiency, detecting mathematical patterns and teaching recursion and iteration. The author concludes that although the conjecture remains unsolved, tools like CollatzR facilitate experimentation and understanding of this fascinating problem.
title: Exploring the Collatz Conjecture with CollatzR

title: Homepage
